FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Vol 175 A 1900

SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 164. }

HEADQUARTERS DIVISION OF CUBA,
Havana, September 21, 1900.

1. Leave of absence for fifteen (15) days, with permission
to go beyond the limits of the Division, is hereby granted
Acting Assistant Surgeon Aristides Agramonte, U. S. Army.

2. The following named enlisted men of the Signal Corps,
U. S. Army, will proceed by the first available government
transport to New York City, New York, thence to Fort
Myer, Virginia, reporting upon arrival to the commanding
officer for duty:

Corporal William S. Cate, in charge,
Private William G. Merrill,
Private Jesse G. Strickenburg.

The Quartermaster's Department will furnish the neces-
sasy transportation, and the Subsistence Department travel
rations for two (2) days.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.
BY COMMAND OF MAJOR GENERAL WOOD:

H. L. SCOTT,
Adjutant General.

The sentence is confirmed to date October 15, 1900, and
will be duly executed. Fort Columbus, New York Harbor,
is designated as the place of confinement, to which point
the prisoner will be sent upon further orders from these
Headquarters.

5. Private George W. Cade, Hospital Corps, U. S. Army,
having been tried by a general court-martial convened at
Santa Clara Battery, Havana, Cuba, and found guilty of
drunkenness on duty, in violation of the 38th Article of
War, and conduct to the prejudice of good order and
military discipline, in violation of the 62d Article of War,
evidence of two (2) previous convictions having been
considered by the court, was sentenced “To be dishonorably
discharged the service of the United States, forfeiting all pay and
allowances, and to be confined at hard labor at such place as the
reviewing authority may direct for one (1) year.”

In the foregoing case of private George W. Cade, Hospital
Corps, U. S. Army, the proceedings, findings and sentence
are approved to date October 15, 1900. The period of
confinement is mitigated to confinement at hard labor for
six months and as thus mitigated will be duly executed.
Fort Columbus, New York Harbor, is designated as the
place of confinement, to which point the prisoner will be
sent upon further orders from these Headquarters.

6. Private Thomas Baynes, Battery I, 2d Artillery, having
been tried by a general court-martial convened at Santa
Clara Battery, Havana, Cuba, and found guilty of absence
without leave, in violation of the 32d Article of War,
and absence from guard mount, in violation of the 33d
Article of War, evidence of four (4) previous convictions
having been considered by the court, was sentenced “To
forfeit ten (10) dollars per month for four (4) months.”

The sentence is confirmed and will be duly executed.
Private Baynes will be released from confinement and
restored to duty with his battery.

7. The leave of absence for fifteen (15) days granted to
Acting Assistant Surgeon Aristides Agramonte, U. S. Army,
in paragraph 1, Special Orders No. 164, current series,
these Headquarters, is extended three (3) days.

BY COMMAND OF MAJOR GENERAL WOOD:
H. L. SCOTT,
Adjutant General.

S. O. 182 Hdqts Div Cuba
Havana Oct 16, 1900
